Package ch.idsia.crema.factor.credal

Interface SeparatelySpecified<F extends SeparatelySpecified<F>>

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    SeparateLinearFactor<F>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    BooleanFactor, ConditionalFactor, IntervalFactor, SeparateFactor, SeparateHalfspaceFactor, SeparatelySpecifiedCredalFactor, VertexFactor
    public interface SeparatelySpecified<F extends SeparatelySpecified<F>>
    A separately specified Factor has a for each possible combination of its "grouping" domain. Usually this domain corresponds with the conditioning domain. The remaining part of the factor's domain is the Data domain. Grouping and Data domain do not overlap and, when combined must be equal to the complete domain obtained by GenericFactor.getDomain().

    Author:
    david

    • Method Summary

      Modifier and Type Method Description
      F filter​(int variable, int state)
      A separately specified factor must be able to filter out given variables on the grouping side of the factor.
      Strides getDataDomain()
      The domain of the rest of the domain.
      Strides getSeparatingDomain()
      The domain of the separated part.
      default F sortParents()
      Sorts the parents following the global variable order

    • Method Detail

      • getSeparatingDomain

        Strides getSeparatingDomain()
        The domain of the separated part. This is usually the conditioning of the Factor. This side must not overlap with the data domain returned by getDataDomain().
        Returns:

      • getDataDomain

        Strides getDataDomain()
        The domain of the rest of the domain. Together with getSeparatingDomain() it will form the complete domain of the object.
        Returns:

      • filter

        F filter​(int variable,
         int state)
        A separately specified factor must be able to filter out given variables on the grouping side of the factor.
        Parameters:
        variable -
        state -
        Returns:

      • sortParents

        default F sortParents()
        Sorts the parents following the global variable order
        Returns:
